title: Aesthetics
summary: Aesthetics is the branch of philosophy concerned with beauty, art, and taste — asking what makes something beautiful, what art is, and whether aesthetic judgments are objective.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Ethics
summary: Ethics is the branch of philosophy that investigates morality — what is right and wrong, good and bad, what we owe to each other, and how we should live.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Philosophy of Religion
summary: Philosophy of religion is the philosophical examination of religious beliefs, practices, and experience — asking whether belief in God is rational and addressing the problem of evil.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Philosophy of Law
summary: Philosophy of law — also called jurisprudence — asks fundamental questions about the nature, purpose, and basis of law, including the relationship between law and morality.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Theology
summary: Theology is faith seeking understanding — the disciplined study of God, revelation, and religious doctrine. From classical arguments for God's existence to the distinctive doctrines of the restored gospel, theology explores what God has revealed.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints
summary: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is a Christian faith founded through the prophet Joseph Smith in 1830, believing in the restoration of Christ's original church, continuing revelation, and the fullness of the gospel.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Christian History
summary: Christian history spans two thousand years, from the ministry of Jesus Christ to the global faith of over 2 billion believers today — including the Great Apostasy, the medieval church, the Reformation, and the Restoration.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Bible
summary: The Bible is the foundational scripture of Christianity — a library of books spanning thousands of years of God's dealings with mankind. Latter-day Saints revere the King James Version as the word of God, complemented by additional scripture.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Doctrine and Covenants
summary: The Doctrine and Covenants is a collection of divine revelations received primarily by Joseph Smith, addressing the restored Church directly in the modern era — covering church organization, priesthood, cosmic theology, and the afterlife.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Pearl of Great Price
summary: The Pearl of Great Price is one of the four standard works of the LDS Church, containing the Book of Moses, the Book of Abraham, Joseph Smith—History, and the Articles of Faith, restoring ancient truths and clarifying LDS doctrine.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Probability Theory
summary: Probability theory is the branch of mathematics that quantifies uncertainty and studies random phenomena. It underpins statistics, machine learning, physics, finance, and all modern data-driven decision-making.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Algebra
summary: Algebra is the branch of mathematics that uses letters and symbols to represent numbers and quantities, allowing us to write general rules and solve equations. It is the gateway to all higher mathematics.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Trigonometry
summary: Trigonometry is the branch of mathematics studying relationships between angles and sides of triangles. Essential for navigation, physics, and engineering, it provides the mathematical foundation for wave analysis and periodic phenomena.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Physics
summary: Physics is the most fundamental of the natural sciences — the study of matter, energy, space, and time. From Newton's laws to Einstein's relativity and quantum mechanics, it drives every major technological revolution.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Isaac Newton
summary: Sir Isaac Newton (1643–1727) was an English mathematician and physicist who formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation, co-invented calculus, and laid the foundation for classical mechanics and the scientific worldview.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Leonhard Euler
summary: Leonhard Euler (1707–1783) was a Swiss mathematician who made foundational contributions to calculus, number theory, graph theory, and physics. The most prolific mathematician in history, his notation still forms the backbone of modern mathematics.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Leonardo da Vinci
summary: Leonardo da Vinci (1452–1519) was an Italian Renaissance polymath — painter, scientist, engineer, and inventor. Creator of the Mona Lisa and The Last Supper, he is the supreme example of the Renaissance ideal of universal genius.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Renaissance
summary: The Renaissance was a transformative cultural movement that began in 14th-century Italy and spread across Europe, marking the transition from the medieval world to the modern era through humanism, art, science, and the revival of classical learning.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Crusades
summary: The Crusades were a series of religious wars (1095–1291) launched by the papacy to recover the Holy Land from Muslim control. Complex in motivation and devastating in impact, they permanently shaped Christian-Muslim relations and medieval Europe.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Reformation
summary: The Protestant Reformation was a 16th-century religious revolution launched by Martin Luther that permanently split Western Christianity, reshaped European politics, and — from an LDS perspective — providentially prepared the world for the Restoration of the gospel.
author: EduWiki Team

title: J.R.R. Tolkien
summary: J.R.R. Tolkien (1892–1973) was an English author, poet, and Oxford professor whose devout Catholic faith and love of mythology gave the world Middle-earth — The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings.
author: EduWiki Team

title: C.S. Lewis
summary: C.S. Lewis (1898–1963) was a British author and Christian apologist whose works — from Mere Christianity to The Chronicles of Narnia — have profoundly influenced millions, including many Latter-day Saints.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Getting Started with EduWiki
summary: An introduction to using and navigating EduWiki.
author: EduWiki Admin

title: How to Create a New Article
summary: Step-by-step guide to adding a new article to EduWiki using the .wmd format.
author: EduWiki Admin

title: WMD Format Reference
summary: Complete reference for the .wmd (Wiki Markdown) format used to write EduWiki articles.
author: EduWiki Admin

title: Formatting Guide
summary: Learn how to use headings, lists, tables, and other text formatting in EduWiki articles.
author: EduWiki Admin

title: Interactive Components Guide
summary: Learn how to embed Desmos graphs, dropdowns, LaTeX math, and other interactive components.
author: EduWiki Admin

title: Quantum Mechanics
summary: Quantum mechanics is the branch of physics that describes the behavior of matter and energy at atomic and subatomic scales, revealing a world of probability, wave-particle duality, and fundamental uncertainty.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Theory of Relativity
summary: Einstein's theory of relativity — both special and general — revolutionized our understanding of space, time, gravity, and the universe, replacing Newton's classical mechanics for extreme speeds and massive objects.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Assembly Language
summary: Assembly language is a low-level programming language that provides a direct, human-readable representation of machine code instructions, giving programmers precise control over hardware.
author: EduWiki Team
